text:
Have anyone here worked with *dynamic mega menus* in HubSpot CMS and can show some *examples*, *pitfalls* and *best practices*?
The 1st column should be static, while the others are dynamic - the number of columns can vary and it's also need to choose button/cta style and add/remove icon with positioning left or above text content.

_I added a image of Mondays dynamic menu as reference._
or just reach out to me and we can have a chat about how you usually setup something like this

I need some help in understanding what the problem is. Can someone with expertise and knowledge assist me with this issue? Thank you.

Hi all, I need to get data from logged user with SSO login on custom private web pages created with CMS Hub. For example, I want to show contact name of the logged user in page content. Is it possibile and How?
<https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonCloudFront/latest/DeveloperGuide/Invalidation.html|https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonCloudFront/latest/DeveloperGuide/Invalidation.html>
You need to purge the cache :)

hey daniel! my name is maggie, i'm the pm of a HubSpot tool called custom behavioral events, which is (imo but biased) the best way to get this kind of data into HubSpot. we have a couple of different offerings:
• track specific actions on a site or app with the event visualizer creation tool or custom javascript functionality
• track activity from any bespoke tool or tools like amplitude or hightouch using our API
• manually import spreadsheets of event data, which is great for migrations, backfills, offline data etc. 
lmk if you have questions or wanna chat about it more. theres some key difference between custom events and timeline events, timeline events are super lightweight, good for having things show up on the timeline, but this data cant be used across a lot of HubSpot, whereas custom events can be used across segmentation, automation, and reporting

Hi y'all, I'm Brennen - I just joined the Developer Slack. I'm trying to troubleshoot the DocuSign integration and was wondering if anyone here has any experience with it. Basically we need to send an agreement to be signed by our donors, and we would like to populate the document with a combination of company and custom fields. I thought sending it from the Company record and then choosing a Contact as the recipient would solve this, but I seem to keep running into issues. I chatted with DocuSigns Developer support yesterday too and went through the logs and it seems to be working as expected on their end. If this solution doesnt work, I would also like to use the HubSpot and DocuSign API's to create a custom solution, but I am not sure how this would work or where I would actually place the code for this to work.

:wave: Hi everyone!

Happy to join the community.  I'm struggling with a custom code block.  I need to re-format all the phone numbers that come in to my account with just the 10 digits, no special characters and no "1" in the area code (I only have US customers).  I got the custom code block from <https://www.HubSpot.com/programmable-automation-use-cases> but have no idea how to implement my secret, or if it's setup correctly.

Any help or guidance would be amazing!

Welcome to the community, glad to have you here!

To get your API key that you’ll be including as a secret, you’ll need to go into your portal settings and create a new private app with the appropriate permissions. (*Settings > Account Setup > Integrations > Private App > Create a Private App*) Once created, you should be presented with an authentication key that you can reveal and copy.

To use that key within a custom code action, you’ll want to add it as a secret. To add a secret to a custom code workflow action, edit the action and make sure you have the *Edit Action* tab selected. Under *Secrets*, select *Add Secret*. Give your secret a name (conventionally, this would be in all-caps and underscore delineated. ie `MY_SECRET_NAME`) and paste the API key from your private app as the value.

To access that key within your action, you can retrieve it from the `process.env` environment variables object:
```const HS_AUTH_KEY = process.env.MY_SECRET_NAME```
Hope this helps!
Thanks <@U04AQA0QM8E>!
Will try it out and let you know :slightly_smiling_face:
<@U04AQA0QM8E> What do I choose for scopes?

That depends on what you’re using the API to retrieve, and what endpoints you’re trying to call. Typically, the documentation for whatever API you’re trying to hit will indicate the required scopes.

That said, I just assumed you needed to make an API call, since you’d mentioned secrets. If you don’t actually need to hit an API endpoint, you can skip private apps, API keys, and secrets altogether — you can just take in inputs from the workflow via the *Property to include in code* section.
